data.title: The 50 Best Movie Scores of All Time
data.meta_description: From Eraserhead to Batman, Under the Skin to Blue Velvet, these are the greatest original compositions for film
data.text:
With the Oscars coming up this Sunday, Pitchfork is celebrating with our first Music & Movies week.

Now that we‚Äôve looked at the best soundtracks in film, let‚Äôs turn to the best scores. We‚Äôre defining scores as original music composed for a film, with recurring motifs and almost always without vocals. This type of work is often the result of a collaboration between a composer and director, and created in tandem with a movie to steadily enhance the narrative onscreen. Put another way: Whereas a soundtrack highlights moments of a movie, a score blankets the entire film. (We‚Äôre only looking at narrative films in this list; we are not including documentaries.)

A great original score is an art form in itself: While it serves the director‚Äôs vision, it can also stand alone as its own immersive listen. As you‚Äôll see below, the original score is a beloved medium for musicians, who often have a favorite one they can point to immediately. And sometimes, musicians who‚Äôve found fame with their own songs can channel those same gifts into film work. So let‚Äôs raise the curtain by talking to two composers who are part of an innovative new vanguard that‚Äôs creating today‚Äôs most exciting movie music.

‚ÄúThe Weaker the Executive, the More Notes You Get‚Äù: A Conversation With Geoff Barrow and Ben Salisbury

In their film scores, composing duo Geoff Barrow (Portishead, Beak>) and Ben Salisbury shun many tropes of the form. Instead of saccharine strings and bright horns, they favor dense, swampy atmospheres and pulsing electronics, creating soundscapes that unsettle and fascinate. After their tense, brooding work for Alex Garland‚Äôs 2014 thriller Ex-Machina won widespread acclaim, they partnered again on Garland‚Äôs Annihilation, their surreal tones adding new layers of disorientation to the sci-fi mystery. Their latest film, Julius Onah‚Äôs Luce, recently premiered at Sundance. Here, they talk about the art of film scoring.

Pitchfork: What do you get creatively out of scoring films?

Geoff Barrow: It‚Äôs opened up a whole world for me that I never really thought existed. It challenges you every day. I love the idea of using sound to explore things like misdirection, to make a person come across as being victimized while knowing that they are the worst person in the world. I absolutely love it.

Ben Salisbury: For me, as simple as it sounds, it‚Äôs the combination of music and picture. I‚Äôm a frustrated filmmaker as much as I am a composer, and I love being part of the collaborative filmmaking process. Sometimes it‚Äôs not even about the big musical moments; there might be little moments where I know that I‚Äôm changing the audience‚Äôs temperature of a film‚Äîthat you‚Äôve twisted their melon. That is very satisfying.

What are some of your personal favorite scores?

Barrow: Ben and I really bonded over Planet of the Apes. John Carpenter‚Äôs Assault on Precinct 13 was big for me‚Äîwhat he managed to convey emotionally, yet so simply, was incredible.

Salisbury: Jaws, Star Wars, Bernard Herrmann, Jerry Goldsmith. More recently: Solaris, You Were Never Really Here, Under the Skin.

Geoff, you come from a nontraditional film scoring background where you have creative autonomy over every aspect of your work. How have you found the transition to serving somebody else‚Äôs vision?

Barrow: Quite difficult. I read something by a music supervisor the other day who said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice when you don‚Äôt notice the music in a film,‚Äù and I thought, What a prick. But this isn‚Äôt an ego blast; you are working for the better of the film. It‚Äôs not about you and you have to get that into your head. I‚Äôm pretty honest in meetings. I don‚Äôt want to waste my time or theirs and, so far, it‚Äôs been OK. I‚Äôve walked away from a few things, especially if they want anything like Portishead. I‚Äôm not going to try and copy myself.

What‚Äôs the biggest lesson you‚Äôve learned from moving into this world?

Barrow: Don‚Äôt ever deliver anything you wouldn‚Äôt be proud of a single second appearing on film because sometimes, when you hand over a rushed rough version to test mood, you‚Äôre no longer in control of what gets done with that music. Also, the weaker the executive, the more notes you get about the music.

Ben, you‚Äôve been a composer for over 20 years. How have things changed?

Salisbury: It‚Äôs quite easy to make a feature film compared to decades ago‚Äîyou can make a film on a phone and get your mate in a band to do the score on a laptop. When I started, you needed so much kit to score films, it was quite an undertaking.

This remains a very male-dominated job. Of the 250 highest-grossing films of 2018, only 6 percent of composers were women.

Salisbury: It definitely is, and we need to do whatever we can to change it‚Äîfor equality reasons but also because you‚Äôre missing out on so much. It‚Äôs like cutting off half the creative ideas available to you. Why would you do that?

Barrow: It‚Äôs appalling but it‚Äôs going to change. There are so many more open-minded directors coming through that I think that change is already happening.

What are some of the biggest differences between the music and film industries?

Barrow: Film makes the music industry look like a toy town. It‚Äôs frightening how absolutely pure evil some people are in the film industry. But I get a kick out of navigating through that world. When I make music with Beak> or Portishead, there is nobody telling me how it should be done, but there‚Äôs also more longevity in film. The music industry is basically a support system for new artists and most people expect you to quit being in a rock band by 35, but in film, people do it right until the end of their lives.

Interview by Daniel Dylan Wray

Listen to selections from this list on our Spotify playlist and Apple Music playlist.

50.

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (2000)

A landmark of Asian cinema, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon was the result of close collaboration between composer Tan Dun and director Ang Lee. Alongside famed cellist Yo-Yo Ma, Dun and Lee worked for four years to conceptualize a movie that would introduce Western audiences to martial arts as a historical form, rather than simply violent entertainment. Just as the film bridged the East and West‚Äîit remains the top-grossing foreign film of all time in the U.S.‚ÄîDun‚Äôs breathtaking score melds elements of his upbringing and traditional Chinese instrumentation with the classical training he received later in America.

The star here is Yo-Yo Ma; Dun would probably agree, as he‚Äôs called him the ‚Äúspiritual glue‚Äù of the writing process. His performances breathe elegance across the entire score, and in the film, his percussive thumps and pizzicato strums are interspersed brilliantly between punches and kicks. The most powerful moment comes in ‚ÄúYearning of the Sword,‚Äù where Ma‚Äôs cello concedes center stage to a Chinese erhu, a sorrowful two-stringed instrument. The two trade melodies, highlighting their distinctive timbral differences before eventually reaching a wistful harmony. ‚ÄìNoah Yoo

Listen: Tan Dun and Yo-Yo Ma, ‚ÄúYearning of the Sword‚Äù

49.

Trouble Man (1972)

As Curtis Mayfield‚Äôs Super Fly and Isaac Hayes‚Äô Shaft took Blaxploitation soundtracks to new heights, Marvin Gaye also found his groove in film music. The Trouble Man score serves the gun-toting, fist-flying, cheesy dialogue-spouting movie just fine, with its smooth grooves cushioning the action, and Gaye‚Äôs lyrics amplifying the bullish attitude of the lead character, but it‚Äôs most potent as a standalone listen.

Trouble Man was released between the politically charged What‚Äôs Going On and the sexually driven Let‚Äôs Get It On, finding Gaye at his artistic peak. The score is largely instrumental with suave horns, funky grooves, pulsing synthesizer, and sparse drums. Yet even when removed from its visual context, the music remains inherently cinematic. Gaye is so reserved with his own vocal contributions that when they soar through the honeyed instrumentations, they greet you like a long-lost friend. Gaye clearly took his role as producer seriously; he holds back his voice and lets the studio sing instead. ‚ÄìDaniel Dylan Wray

Listen: Marvin Gaye, ‚ÄúTrouble Man‚Äù

48.

Teesri Manzil (1966)

Composer Rahul Dev Burman racked up over 250 film credits in his lifetime, making him one of the most prolific artists in the already bustling Bollywood factory. One of his most enduring scores is also one of his earliest: his crackling collaboration with director Vijay Anand for 1966‚Äôs Teesri Manzil, a Hitchcock-like thriller that remains one of Bollywood‚Äôs best-loved films. It marked the first time that Burman and Anand collaborated, a partnership that would last into the ‚Äô80s.

With Teesri Manzil, Burman paired Indian cinema‚Äôs lavish orchestrations with surf music‚Äôs whiplash guitar, then added rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll‚Äôs rollicking sax and booming backbeat. Burman also deployed iconic playback singers like Mohammed Rafi and Asha Bhosle to duet on the film‚Äôs biggest numbers. With dizzying choreography set against surreal set pieces, songs like ‚ÄúOh Haseena Zulfon Waali‚Äù and ‚ÄúAaja Aaja‚Äù remain beloved in India to this day. ‚ÄìAndy Beta

Listen: Mohammed Rafi, ‚ÄúDeewana Mujshe Nahin‚Äù

47.

Batman (1989)

In his score for Tim Burton‚Äôs Batman, Danny Elfman starts somewhere appropriate for our hero: the minor key. The composer‚Äôs iconic ‚ÄúThe Batman Theme‚Äù is fortissimo in all the right ways, with thunderous drums and a brass section so brash, it would make Mahler blush. It‚Äôs riveting and, most importantly, not at all menacing; it's just a bit dark, nodding subtly to Bruce Wayne‚Äôs antihero tendencies without taking him too seriously or squashing the invigorating feeling of watching him save the day.

‚ÄúThe Batman Theme‚Äù is also pure fun, befitting a story about an unhinged rich man who spends his free time spying on people from a cave. The playfulness shows up elsewhere in the film, such as when Elfman uses ‚ÄúPhotos/Beautiful Dreamer‚Äù to soundtrack the Joker‚Äôs gleeful destruction, or turning the Joker‚Äôs demented rooftop dance with Vicki Vale into a ‚ÄúWaltz to the Death.‚Äù In contrast to the grim tendencies of Christopher Nolan‚Äôs Batman reboot‚Äîcomplete with a joyless, orchestral score by Hans Zimmer‚ÄîDanny Elfman shows that a superhero movie is at its best when it‚Äôs a thrilling, snappy spectacle. ‚ÄìMatthew Strauss

Listen: Danny Elfman, ‚ÄúThe Batman Theme‚Äù

Listen: Henry Mancini, ‚ÄúThe Pink Panther Theme‚Äù

45.

Les Stances √† Sophie (1971)

In 1969, the Art Ensemble of Chicago relocated to Paris, where they hypnotized the film director Mosh√© Mizrahi in concert. Struck by ‚Äúthe way they attacked music, like they could do anything they wanted,‚Äù he asked them to score his adaptation of Les Stances √† Sophie by the French feminist novelist Christiane Rochefort. The result is often jarringly at odds with the film‚Äôs visuals, pulling attention from screen to speaker and stealing scenes, but their riotous work succeeds in capturing the push-pull dynamics and clashing philosophies of the central couple, a sexually liberated woman and her more uptight husband. The recording features Fontella Bass (singer of the R&B hit ‚ÄúRescue Me‚Äù) on the memorable ‚ÄúTh√®me De Yoyo,‚Äù which melds her infectious vocals, explosive Can-like drums, silky bass-led funk, and detonating brass. The score blazes with such vitality and momentum that the music‚Äôs legacy eclipses the largely forgotten film. ‚ÄìDaniel Dylan Wray

Listen: The Art Ensemble of Chicago, ‚ÄúTh√®me De Yoyo‚Äù

44.

Jackie (2018)

In not much time, Mica Levi has made a name for herself as a master of cacophonous anxiety. After scoring the eerie extraterrestrial film Under the Skin, she brought that disquiet to Pablo Larra√≠n‚Äôs Jackie, starring Natalie Portman as the grieving First Lady in the days after JFK‚Äôs assassination. Levi elevates the film out of conventional biopic territory with its dreamlike, frightening ambience; her strings sound ominously off, as if someone has accidentally landed on the wrong note, and the entire score doubles down on that pebble-in-the-shoe feeling. The musical Camelot plays a big role in the film, most notably in the scene where the newly widowed Jackie drinks wine alone in the White House. But overall, Levi‚Äôs creeping strings provide the minor-key backbone for this snapshot of a woman in mourning as the world watches her. ‚ÄìKristen Yoonsoo Kim

Listen: Mica Levi, ‚ÄúBurial‚Äù

43.

Koyaanisqatsi (1982)

Director Godfrey Reggio has never wanted to say what Koyaanisqatsi is about, to pinpoint the message behind his precisely edited slipstream of time-lapse beauty and stunning slow-motion. Juxtaposing the ancient majesty of nature with the mechanized might of human endeavor, Koyaanisqatsi is either an environmentalist‚Äôs nightmare or an industrialist‚Äôs ode to invention and conquest, depending on how you see the world. Philip Glass‚Äô overwhelming score, which runs largely uninterrupted for the length of the film, is a similar litmus test: During ‚ÄúThe Grid,‚Äù do you connect with the perfectly controlled voices or the pulsing synthesizers? Is ‚ÄúSlo Mo People‚Äù the sound of existential satisfaction or anguish, ‚ÄúProphecies‚Äù a clarion call to action or a dream for the future? Ultimately, is Koyaanisqatsi a celebration of what we have done or a lamentation of what we will do? A microcosm of a million moving parts, Glass‚Äô score makes everything feel important and urgent, with enormous dynamic sweeps and interwoven melodies that seem to multiply and surround you, giving you no choice but to at least consider the questions he and Reggio raise. Koyaanisqatsi marked the start of Glass‚Äô career as a major film composer, but it also helped redefine how tightly bound film and sound can be, and how much they can say together. ‚ÄìGrayson Haver Currin

Listen: Philip Glass, ‚ÄúProphecies‚Äù

42.

Suspiria (1977)

Italian prog-rock band Goblin‚Äôs score for Dario Argento‚Äôs Suspiria is routinely exalted by horror connoisseurs and electronic music producers alike. Suspiria nostalgia reached an all-time high in 2018 when founding Goblin member Claudio Simonetti led a tour performing the score to screenings of the film; also, none other than Thom Yorke filled Goblin‚Äôs shoes onscreen, providing music for a chilly, cerebral Suspiria remake by Luca Guadagnino. But what an unlikely candidate for hushed reverence: The original picture is gloriously over-the-top and irreverent, with its intentionally cartoonish color scheme, stiffly dubbed dialogue, and lurid occult violence.

Goblin‚Äôs score heaps on the gaudy extravagance and visceral thrills. From The Exorcist-like bells to Halloween-presaging synths, funked-out guitar to prim harpsichord, trippy tabla to creepy screams, all is fair game so long as it‚Äôs suitably wild. These days, synthesizers and cinema are no longer strange bedfellows, and ‚Äúcult classics‚Äù have graduated to become simply ‚Äúclassics,‚Äù but Goblin‚Äôs work on Suspiria still sounds wonderfully deranged. ‚ÄìMarc Hogan

Listen: Goblin, ‚ÄúSuspiria‚Äù

41.

Blue Velvet (1986)

‚ÄúYou fucking get that thing, man. There are 27 zillion songs in the world. I don‚Äôt want one of them. I want this song,‚Äù David Lynch told producer Fred Caruso. He was talking about This Mortal Coil‚Äôs ethereal masterpiece ‚ÄúSong to the Siren,‚Äù which he envisioned as the backdrop for a crucial scene in his film Blue Velvet, a surreal mystery bound up in straitjacketed camp‚Äîa kind of claustrophobic Norman Rockwell nightmare.

Lynch didn‚Äôt get the song. Instead, the director tasked Angelo Badalamenti, a young composer he had hired as Isabella Rossellini‚Äôs vocal coach, with creating a replacement. It ‚Äúshould be a song that floats on the sea of time,‚Äù Lynch told him. And that‚Äôs exactly what Badalamenti came up with in ‚ÄúMysteries of Love,‚Äù in which a then-unknown singer named Julee Cruise coos coolly over beatific synth pads. (The title and lyrics were Lynch‚Äôs.) Badalamenti‚Äôs score for the film‚Äîthe first of many he would compose for Lynch‚Äîproves perfectly suited to the director‚Äôs sneaky visual style, encompassing lounge jazz, sinister atmospheres, and winking twists on cinematic convention. The ‚ÄúMain Title‚Äù theme, repeated frequently, slices back and forth, pawing at the spongy ground: Like the film‚Äôs narrative itself, it progresses haltingly, two steps forward, one step back, unleashing unimaginable darkness as it burrows deep into the subconscious. ‚ÄìPhilip Sherburne

Listen: Angelo Badalamenti, ‚ÄúMain Title‚Äù

40.

Jaws (1975)

Steven Spielberg‚Äôs thriller opens with the destruction of innocence. A young couple run off to the ocean to skinny dip; while the woman waits for her beau, who is engaged in a drunken battle with his trousers, she splashes around in the moonlight. Then, it begins. Dun nun‚Ä¶dun nun‚Ä¶. The girl is a goner. With just two repeating notes, played with increasing urgency by a 19-piece string and horn section, composer John Williams traumatized beachgoers forever and gave cinema‚Äôs newest nightmare an unforgettable theme. Never again has a tuba been used for such evil.

Despite its primal horror, the Jaws theme would not be as effective were it not for the less-ominous orchestrations in the film‚Äôs first half, like the swashbuckling ‚ÄúPromenade (Tourists on the Menu)‚Äù and the cheerful ‚ÄúOut to Sea.‚Äù The idyllic New England summer these moments establish make the devastation of the shark all the more cruel. By the time the film‚Äôs crew of Captain Ahabs set sail to kill their aquatic demon once and for all, the score pummels relentlessly, emerging from the sea to wreak havoc. Like Psycho before it, Jaws showed music‚Äôs ability to convey terror, chilling viewers to their cores. ‚ÄìQuinn Moreland

Listen: John Williams, ‚ÄúMain Title (Theme From Jaws)‚Äù

39.

The Tale of Genji (1987)

The Tale of Genji, written in the 11th century by a noblewoman named Shikibu Murasaki, has been called the world‚Äôs first novel. Detailing courtly love in Heian society, the sprawling, seductive book was partially adapted into the 1987 anime film from Gisabur≈ç Sugii. The film may only cover the first few chapters, but the soundtrack from Haruomi Hosono imparts a singular charge.

Hosono is a legend in 20th century Japanese music, from his tenure in Yellow Magic Orchestra to his own wide-ranging solo work‚Äîbut even amid his decades of music, the score for Genji stands apart. His telltale electronics hover in the background as he accentuates koto, drums, and bamboo flute, mixing Japanese court music with ambient into a mix that defies characterization. ‚ÄìAndy Beta

Listen: Haruomi Hosono, ‚ÄúÊúàË™≠ (Tsukiyomi)‚Äù

Listen: Ennio Morricone, ‚ÄúDeborah‚Äôs Theme‚Äù

37.

Walkabout (1971)

In Nicolas Roeg‚Äôs film, two British children stranded in the outback are rescued and guided back to ‚Äúcivilization‚Äù by an indigenous Australian boy‚Äîscare quotes around the C-word, for Walkabout is a rhapsodic elegy for nature and our lost innocence. Because there‚Äôs only sporadic dialogue (Roeg described the script as ‚Äúa 14-page prose poem‚Äù) and the six-year-old brother and his teenage sister have been brought up in typically post-imperial stiff-upper-lip fashion, nearly all the emotional eloquence in the movie is supplied by the score. Waltjingu Bandilil‚Äôs eerie didgeridoo and Karlheinz Stockhausen‚Äôs disorienting tape-piece Hymnen conjure the unknowable majesty of the arid landscape and its scorching extremes of weather. But it‚Äôs veteran film composer John Barry who establishes the prevailing mood with his piercingly poignant orchestrations. A stirring choral theme redolent of a school song, ‚ÄúThe Children‚Äù evokes the simple-hearted hope and accepting obedience with which kids face the world. The horn fanfares of ‚ÄúThe Journey‚Äù conjure a storybook-adventure air, mirroring the way that the youngest child in particular processes his predicament. Above all, there‚Äôs the gently devastating, recurring main theme, a patient pulse of harpsichord over which wistful woodwinds pipe and tender violins soar and swoop. ‚ÄìSimon Reynolds

Listen: John Barry, ‚ÄúThe Children‚Äù

36.

Anatomy of a Murder (1959)

At one point in the lively 1959 legal drama Anatomy of a Murder, a small-town woman caught up in a homicide case questions her lawyer‚Äôs taste in records. ‚ÄúAren‚Äôt lawyers supposed to like music?‚Äù responds the weary attorney, played by James Stewart. She shoots back: ‚ÄúWell, not that kind of music!‚Äù She‚Äôs talking about jazz, which was just beginning to be used in movies at the time, and Duke Ellington‚Äôs work on Anatomy of a Murder marked the first time a black composer wrote a full-length score for a major film. In an interview, the legendary bandleader made his intentions clear. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not playing semi-classical stuff or symphonic music,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs strictly Duke Ellington music.‚Äù

So it is. In the late ‚Äô50s, Ellington was enjoying a career renaissance, and his score features the sort of swinging, big-band tunes he made his name on decades prior. But most effective are the more somber compositions that add depth to Anatomy‚Äôs explicit-for-the-time story, which revolves around an ethically murky case of rape, jealousy, murder, and the vagaries of the law. The film is famously ambiguous, smudging the line between hero and villain, and Ellington and his orchestra‚Äôs improvisations work best when they achingly tug at that sense of reasonable doubt. ‚ÄìRyan Dombal

35.

Ceddo (1977)

In the late ‚Äô70s, the Cameroonian saxophonist Manu Dibango was already legendary on dancefloors for his disco-defining 1972 hit ‚ÄúSoul Makossa,‚Äù which would go on to form the basis of Michael Jackson‚Äôs ‚ÄúWanna Be Startin‚Äô Somethin‚Äô.‚Äù But in 1977, Dibango reached across borders and genres to score the Senegalese director Ousmane Semb√®ne‚Äôs film Ceddo. Semb√®ne‚Äôs unflinching historical films often looked at atrocities from Senegal‚Äôs history and, like past works of his, Ceddo was banned in his country. No doubt the film‚Äôs grim portrayal of Islam and Christianity in past centuries had something to do with it, showing how these religions feasted on the slave trade, turning human beings into commodities. Buoying such grim imagery is Dibango‚Äôs music: His sax and vibraphone mingle with piano, guitar, and drums to create a highlight of ‚Äô70s African cinema, revealing Dibango to be a diverse and deeply funky composer. ‚ÄìAndy Beta

Listen: Manu Dibango, ‚ÄúCeddo‚Äù

34.

Breakfast at Tiffany‚Äôs (1961)

In Breakfast at Tiffany‚Äôs, Audrey Hepburn portrays a ‚Äúvery lovely, very frightened girl‚Äù who escapes to New York to reinvent herself. While Hepburn‚Äôs performance of Holly Golightly is enchanting, it is arguably Henry Mancini‚Äôs score that most effectively conjures the romance, loneliness, and mystique of the city. Mancini captures all sides of New York, from champagne-soaked parties soundtracked by peacocking big bands to the sultry allure of its seedy underworld.

The heart of Breakfast at Tiffany‚Äôs is indisputably ‚ÄúMoon River,‚Äù which captures Holly‚Äôs longing for love and adventure. Though instrumental and choral renditions of the song bookend the film, the most enduring version is sung by the untrained Hepburn on her character‚Äôs fire escape, hair in a wrap and guitar in hand. Featuring lyrics penned by Hollywood songwriter Johnny Mercer, Hepburn‚Äôs performance of ‚ÄúMoon River‚Äù aches with a genuine wistfulness that transcends the film itself. ‚ÄìQuinn Moreland

Listen: Henry Mancini and His Orchestra, ‚ÄúMoon River‚Äù

33.

La Plan√®te Sauvage (1973)

Whether you perceive La Plan√®te Sauvage‚Äôs strange allegory of giant, blue-skinned Draags and their enslaved, human-sized pet Oms on the planet of Ygam as imparting a lesson in racism, human rights, or animal rights, this early-‚Äô70s animated flick continues to mystify first-graders and grad-school vapers alike. But the film‚Äôs real genius was in tapping Serge Gainsbourg‚Äôs arranger/composer Alain Goraguer for the soundtrack, before he pivoted away from child-friendly fare into scoring French porn. Full of flummoxing wah-wah guitar, ethereal choirs, breathy horns, psychedelic Mellotron, and crisp breakbeats, this score has inspired beat-heads like J Dilla, DJ Shadow, Madlib, and Flying Lotus while also powering tracks for Mac Miller, Big Pun, and Capone-N-Noreaga. Surreal, forlorn, and funky in equal measure, La Plan√®te Sauvage continues to draw generations of producers and rappers into its gravitational field. ‚ÄìAndy Beta

32.

Sicario (2015)

The Stephen Hawking biopic The Theory of Everything made the Oscars take notice of J√≥hann J√≥hannsson as a blockbuster composer, but it was the late experimental musician‚Äôs score for Denis Villeneuve‚Äôs Sicario, released the following year, that proved he could smuggle truly unsettling sounds into Hollywood. Sicario is one of those FBI drug-bust thrillers in which the tension maintains a steady simmer; you can‚Äôt always tell when the action is about to go down because the heroes spend so much time riding around in SUVs. J√≥hannsson‚Äôs score is particularly good in these moments: With its pounding timpani crescendos, venomous string strikes, and deft use of atmospheric dynamics that zoom in and out, the music is a clear sign of not just the danger that looms but the pure evil embodied by the film‚Äôs drug-lord villains. The effect is well captured by ‚ÄúConvoy,‚Äù a composition that hums along anxiously before swarming up at once and surrounding each side in a different kind of instrumental chaos. When the chase finally dies down, the mood is eerily still: They‚Äôll be back. ‚ÄìJillian Mapes

Listen: J√≥hann J√≥hannsson, ‚ÄúConvoy‚Äù

31.

Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence (1983)

The Japanese composer Ryuichi Sakamoto, a member of the electronic band Yellow Magic Orchestra, would go on to win an Oscar for his work on Bernardo Bertolucci‚Äôs The Last Emperor, but his first toe-dip into cinema was Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence. Japanese director Nagisa √îshima‚Äôs English-language feature starred David Bowie as a handsome British major in a prisoner-of-war camp, and costarred Sakamoto himself as a guard. Sakamoto‚Äôs famous piano ballad starts with notes as pure and gentle as raindrops, a friendly reprieve from the World War II backdrop and an antidote for his initially militant character (who, not surprisingly, eventually becomes enamored with Bowie‚Äôs Jack Celliers). Even when the song escalates into a battle anthem, the humanistic melody still shines through. ‚ÄìKristen Yoonsoo Kim

Listen: Ryuichi Sakamoto, ‚ÄúMerry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence‚Äù

30.

The Cook, the Thief, His Wife, and Her Lover (1989)

Peter Greenaway‚Äôs elegantly awful masterpiece is the best version of ‚ÄúThe Aristocrats‚Äù ever told. In a series of seemingly endless camera movements that glide across a feast of violence, nudity, piss, shit, garish colors, and amazing Jean-Paul Gaultier costumes, it chronicles the abuse and humiliation to which a gluttonous, nouveau-riche London gangster played by Michael Gambon subjects everyone in his orbit‚Ä¶ until the worm, as it were, finally turns.

The score by British minimalist and frequent Greenaway collaborator Michael Nyman matches the director's commitment to both restrictive formalism and anything-goes maximalist zeal. The genteel funeral march of ‚ÄúMemorial,‚Äù for example, evolves into a ludicrous saxophone grind. In ‚ÄúMiserere,‚Äù a boy soprano sings at the upper limit of his listeners‚Äô comfort zone. Yet right in the middle of it all, there‚Äôs ‚ÄúFish Beach,‚Äù a backbreaker of a love theme for the adulterous characters played by Helen Mirren and Alan Howard. Here, the lurid flourishes drop away entirely, leaving behind only the repeated sound of something beautiful and doomed. ‚ÄìSean T. Collins

Listen: Michael Nyman, ‚ÄúMemorial‚Äù

29.

Vertigo (1958)

Alfred Hitchcock‚Äôs musical collaborator, Bernard Herrmann, was responsible for some of the most recognizable scores in cinematic history. Some of his best work can be found on Hitchcock‚Äôs obsessive thriller Vertigo, about a man who loses the woman he loves (an enigmatic, platinum-blonde Kim Novak) only to find her plain doppelg√§nger (Novak again, this time brunette), whom he grooms to look exactly like his deceased lover.
